title: Psi Tauri
text:
Psi Tauri, which is <a href="Romanization%20of%20Greek">Latinized</a> from ψ Tauri, is a solitary <a href="star">star</a> in the <a href="zodiac">zodiac</a> <a href="constellation">constellation</a> of <a href="Taurus%20%28constellation%29">Taurus</a>. It has a yellow-white hue and is visible to the naked eye with an <a href="apparent%20visual%20magnitude">apparent visual magnitude</a> of +5.22. The distance to this system, as determined using an annual <a href="parallax">parallax</a> shift of as seen from the Earth, is 90 <a href="light%20year">light year</a>s. It is drifting further away with a <a href="radial%20velocity">radial velocity</a> of +9 km/s.
This object is an <a href="F-type%20main%20sequence%20star">F-type main sequence star</a> with a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> of F1 V, which indicates it is undergoing <a href="stellar%20core">core</a> <a href="hydrogen%20fusion">hydrogen fusion</a>. It is about 1.4 billion years old and is spinning with a <a href="projected%20rotational%20velocity">projected rotational velocity</a> of 45 km/s. The star has 1.6 times the <a href="mass%20of%20the%20Sun">mass</a> and <a href="radius%20of%20the%20Sun">radius of the Sun</a>. It is radiating 4.8 times the <a href="Sun%27s%20luminosity">Sun's luminosity</a> from its <a href="photosphere">photosphere</a> at an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of 7,088 K.
